title: FAQ
text: package computes maximum likelihood estimates (MLE) Erlang distribution (K, Œª) /MLE Erlang-Exponential distribution (K, ŒªErlang, ŒªExponential) observed data.

title: FAQ
text: Erlang‚ÄìExponential distribution describes sum 2 independent random variables: erlang random variable shape parameter K rate parameter, ŒªErlang exponential random variable rate parameter ŒªExponential. Essentially, distribution generalizes Erlang distribution adding extra exponential stage, can either faster slower Erlang stages. allows better approximation empirical distributions varying skewness tail behavior.

title: FAQ
text: algorithm calculates maximum likelihood estimates (MLE) Erlang distribution observed data. Since Erlang shape parameter K must integer, direct optimization K using common optimization libraries non-trivial. address , first minimize negative log-likelihood observed data Gamma distribution respect continuous shape parameter K, using numerical optimization. provides candidate value K can adjusted nearest integers identify maximum likelihood estimates Erlang distribution. exact details explained . search starts initial guess K specified ‚ÄòInitialguessK‚Äô. cost function specified Erlang_Fit_CostFunction.m. function minimized respect K negative log likelihood observed data given Gamma distribution. ‚àílog(‚àè=1NŒªKxiK‚àí1e‚àíŒªxi(K‚àí1)!) - \log \left( \prod_{=1}^N \frac{\lambda^K x_i^{K - 1} e^{-\lambda x_i}}{(K - 1)!} \right) function , xi refers observed data, N refers size observed data K Œª shape scale parameters Gamma distribution. corresponding scale parameter, Œª used evaluation negative log likelihood calculated initial guess K via following relationship, Œº mean observed data: KŒª=Œº \frac{K}{\lambda} = \mu  relationship exists MLE Gamma distribution (extension Erlang). Specifically, relationship arises Gamma MLE conditions: differentiating log-likelihood respect Œª setting 0 yields Œª = K / Œº. leverage relationship search one variable K. Side note: implementation, since MATLAB‚Äôs gampdf related Gamma functions parameterize scale parameter 1/Œª, reciprocal used internally. finding optimal continuous K, floor ‚åäK‚åã ceiling ‚åàK‚åâ value evaluated candidate integer K values finding MLE Erlang Distribution. candidate K, respective Œª computed Œª = K / Œº holds MLE, log-likelihood observed data given Erlang distribution computed. pair integer K* Œª* gives higher log-likelihood selected MLE Erlang Distribution. special case ‚åàK‚åâ = 0, candidate K = 0 admissible Erlang Distribution. Therefore, K = 1 Œª = 1 / Œº MLE distribution. also corresponds exponential distribution mean variance Œª. Assumptions: likelihood observed data given Gamma distribution forms 2D surface continuous variables K Œª. MLE, parameters satisfy K / Œª = Œº, reducing search space 1D line surface. optimal continuous (K, Œª) Gamma found, floor ceiling K selected two corresponding Erlang candidates. method assumes: (1) maximum likelihood found continuous Gamma distribution along line true global maximum, (2) likelihood function along segment floor(K) ceil(K) monotonic continuous, allowing us identify MLE Erlang distribution checking two integer neighbours.

title: FAQ
text: default, algorithm performs adaptive search across range K-values centered around input value K best identify K ‚Äì along corresponding ŒªErlang ŒªExponential ‚Äì maximizes likelihood observed data. ‚ÄòFixedK‚Äô, true specified, algorithm instead computes MLEs (ŒªErlang ŒªExponential) fixed value K (specified input value K). section details algorithm computes MLE fixed input argument K. backbone overall procedure, since adaptive search described earlier simply repeats fixed-K estimation across multiple candidate K values. algorithm calculates MLE (ŒªErlang & ŒªExponential) Erlang-Exponential distribution observed data given input shape parameter K optimizing cost function minimizes negative log likelihood observed data given Erlang-Exponential distribution. optimization starts initial guess ŒªErlang specified ‚ÄòInitialguessErLam‚Äô implemented ErlangExp_Fit_v3_CostFunction.m. negative log likelihood computed using custom function embedded within ErlangExp_DirectInt.m. function outputs pointwise PDF Erlang‚ÄìExponential distribution log-likelihood observed dataset model. Note: custom function performs direct numerical integration convolution Erlang distribution Exponential distribution. expression convolution follows: ŒªErkŒªExp(k‚àí1)!e‚àíŒªExpz‚à´0zxk‚àí1e‚àí(ŒªEr‚àíŒªExp)xdx \frac{\lambda_{Er}^k \lambda_{Exp}}{(k - 1)!} e^{-\lambda_{Exp} z} \int_0^z x^{k - 1} e^{-(\lambda_{Er} - \lambda_{Exp}) x} \, dx  computing negative log likelihood, corresponding ŒªExponential calculated via following relationship, exists MLE function: KŒªErlang+1ŒªExponential=Œº \frac{K}{\lambda_{Erlang}} + \frac{1}{\lambda_{Exponential}} = \mu  pair ŒªErlang & ŒªExponential maximizes log-likelihood selected MLE Erlang-Exponential Distribution observed data. Additional notes optimization: Default parameter bounds specified within optimization ensure stability. particular, lower bound ŒªErlang derived analytical relationship distribution parameters MLE restriction ŒªErlang > 0. addition, small error term (1e-2) added numerical consistency‚Äîprevents undefined behavior optimization.

title: FAQ
text: Assessment goodness--fit estimated Erlang model evaluated parametric bootstrap hypothesis testing via function Erlang_Fit_Pvalue_v2.m null hypothesis (H0) observed data truly come fitted Erlang distribution, alternative hypothesis (H1) data consistent come best fit Erlang Distribution. assessing , test statistic, (T*) first computed observed data fitted Erlang model null hypothesis. Next, n (default n = 10,000) synthetic datasets generated best-fit Erlang model, size empirical dataset. statistics computed synthetic dataset fitted model (without refitting) yields empirical null distribution statistic fitted model. observed statistic (T*) compared null distribution obtain bootstrap p-value (p*), defined proportion bootstrap statistics least extreme observed one. p* mapped binary decision variable q* q* = 0 indicates rejection null hypothesis significance level Œ± (specified ‚ÄòAlpha‚Äô), q* = 1 indicates otherwise. specific choice test statistic determined user-specified ‚Äòpvaloption‚Äô (‚Äòpvaloption‚Äô = 2, 3, 4 correspond distance based test statistics Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov (KS), Anderson‚ÄìDarling (AD), Cram√©r‚Äìvon Mises (CvM) statistic, respectively). additional option ‚Äòpvaloption‚Äô = 1 specifies likelihood-based test, currently remains development. example illustrate , default ‚Äòpvaloption‚Äô = 2 specified, Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov (KS) test statistic used, calculates maximum distance empirical data CDF fitted model CDF. statistic (T*) first computed observed data CDF fitted Erlang model CDF. statistic computed n synthetic datasets fitted Erlang model CDF, producing empirical null distribution assumption null hypothesis true. p-value (p*) calculated proportion bootstrap statistics greater equal observed statistic (T*), .e., quantifies probability observing statistic least extreme empirical one null (H0). chosen significance level Œ±, null rejected p* < Œ± retained otherwise. implementation, decision encoded using binary indicator q q = 0 denotes rejection null (model fails) q = 1 denotes non-rejection null (model passes) Overall, outputs algorithm reported varargout{1} [K*, Œª*, p*, q*, L*] K* Œª* MLE Erlang Distribution, L* corresponding log-likelihood p* q* goodness fit p-value binary decision indicator respectively.

what: Additional note for the Erlang-Exponential Fit
title: FAQ
text: Assessment goodness--fit estimated Erlang model evaluated hypothesis testing via function ErlangExp_Fit_Pvalue_DirectInt.m [theory logic Erlang Goodness Fit Evaluation] Additional Note: Construction CDF using distance-based metrics evaluate goodness--fit: Since closed-form CDF Erlang‚ÄìExponential distribution, cumulative distribution obtained numerically function ErlangExpCDF_DirectInt.m. function first approximates Erlang‚ÄìExponential PDF uniform grid points 0:interval:max(observed data) (default interval = 0.01) using ErlangExp_DirectInt.m. (mentioned, custom function estimates Erlang‚ÄìExponential PDF via direct numerical integration convolution expression). approximate PDF values cumulatively integrated across grid obtain CDF. Interpolation used estimate CDF values observed data points. approximate CDF subsequently used evaluate distance-based test statistics, (.e., maximum distance empirical data CDF fitted model CDF). Note procedure involves two layers numerical integration‚Äîfirst approximate PDF second obtain CDF‚Äîsmall numerical errors can accumulate, results interpreted mind. default interval set 0.01, chosen compromise numerical accuracy computational efficiency: sufficiently fine ensure smooth numerical integration PDF, remaining coarse enough avoid unnecessary computational overhead.

previous_headings: Smallest statistically acceptable K Model (Smallest K)
title: FAQ
text: ‚ÄòSmallestK‚Äô option passed input, algorithm performs search decreasing integer values K identify smallest K still yields adequate model fit. Starting best fit K*, procedure repeatedly lowers K (Œª updated preserve MLE relationship) re-evaluates goodness--fit. continues goodness--fit longer passes significance level Œ± (.e., p* < Œ±), point last accepted K recorded smallest admissible K. corresponding Œª, p-value, binary decision q, log-likelihood reported varargout{2}.

previous_headings: Smallest statistically acceptable K Model (Smallest K)
title: FAQ
text: works way ‚ÄòSmallestK‚Äô option passed input requires starting value K. . additional input ‚ÄòSmallestKValue‚Äô provided, used directly. Otherwise algorithm runs Erlang-Fit function identify smallest admissible K uses starting value Erlang‚ÄìExponential model.

title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: GenErlangFit package aims identify optimal generalized Erlang Erlang‚ÄìExponential model consistent observed time--event data.

title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: install load package GitHub, run commands R console:
code: devtools::install_github("insertuser/generlangfit") library(generlangfit) library(ggplot2)

what: Context and Summary of the Method
title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: Standard compartmental models infectious diseases often assume constant transition rates states, implies exponential distribution ‚Äúwaiting times‚Äù state. (e.g., latent period, infectious period). However, assumption align empirical data many diseases. Linear Chain Trick (LCT) offers computationally tractable alternative modeling state series multiple identical substates, producing Erlang-distributed waiting times (Gamma distribution integer shape parameter). approach combines maximum likelihood parameter estimation non-parametric significance testing prioritize simplest model structures produce waiting times consistent observed data. improve flexibility, incorporate Erlang-Exponential model‚Äîextension standard Erlang distribution adds final exponential stage‚Äî allowing better approximation empirical distributions varying skewness tail behavior. user-friendly package enables modelers fit empirical data build parsimonious, data-driven compartmental models across diverse domains. thorough walk fitting algorithms assumptions can found FAQ vignette linked . vignette serves simple tutorial users can get started package.

title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: general, user needs familiar using one single function GenErlang_Fit.R. default, user runs following line code just empiricaldata argument: function run Erlang Erlang-Exp fit, run goodness fit evaluations addition, search smallest statistically acceptable K models. smallest K model means can found FAQ: Smallest K Model. Users also ability choose specific model like fit data via specifying following input arguments: Note running specific models, arguments need specified first argument function. Erlang-Exponential model, additional input argument K must always provided search optimal K handled differently Erlang. See FAQ: Erlang-Exp Fit. defaults offer efficient first pass analyses, giving users clear initial sense model structures best capture data.
code: GenErlang_Fit(empiricaldata) GenErlang_Fit('Erlang', empiricaldata) GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K)

title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: users familiar default behavior GenErlang_Fit.R, helpful clarify users can customize different aspects fitting workflow. following sections outline main categories options available departing default settings: Fit Options (e.g., changing initial guesses controlling Erlang-exp search K), Goodness--Fit Options (e.g., bootstrap-based confidence intervals p-value estimation), Smallest-K Search tools used model parsimony computational efficiency. subsection explains purpose options, call , situations users may want override defaults.

previous_headings: Using the Package > Model Specific Fitting Options
title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: GenErlang_Fit provides default initialization values optimization routines. Users may optionally supply initial guesses customize fitting process assess robustness results different starting values. Erlang model: initial guess refers number substates, K used optimization. Erlang‚ÄìExponential model: initial guess refers Erlang rate parameterùúÜK provided explicitly user.
code: GenErlang_Fit('Erlang', empiricaldata, 'InitialguessK = VALUE') GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K, 'InitialguessErlam = VALUE')

previous_headings: Using the Package > Model Specific Fitting Options
title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: Erlang‚ÄìExponential model requires manually specifying additional input parameter K. Depending analysis, users may either: Fix K compute MLE model structure, Search window nearby K values automatically detect better-fitting structure. FixedK = TRUE, function performs pure MLE fit given K, using supplied initial conditions. FixedK = FALSE, function expands search include K ¬± user-defined window (KwindowSize), rendering initial guess overrides less relevant optimization repeated across multiple candidate structures.default option FixedK argument provided.
code: GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K, FixedK = TRUE) GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K, FixedK = FALSE, KwindowSize = VALUE)

title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: GenErlang_Fit provides built-tools assessing well fitted model matches empirical distribution. options apply Erlang Erlang‚ÄìExp models include: Choice test statistic (via pvaloption) Significance level (Alpha) Number bootstrap samples (NumBootStraps) detailed description section can found : FAQ: Goodness Fit Evaluation.

previous_headings: Using the Package > Goodness of Fit Options
what: Overriding choice of P Value Computation
title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: Users can select distance measure use evaluating model‚Äôs goodness--fit: ‚ÄúKS‚Äù ‚Äî Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov Statistic ‚ÄúCVM‚Äù ‚Äî Cram√©r‚Äìvon Mises Statistic ‚ÄúAD‚Äù ‚Äî Anderson‚ÄìDarling Statistic ‚ÄúNIL‚Äù ‚Äî skip p-value computation entirely Choosing test statistic modifies bootstrap distribution measure fit.
code: GenErlang_Fit('Erlang', empiricaldata, pvaloption = 'KS', 'CVM', 'AD' or 'NIL') GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K, pvaloption = 'KS', 'CVM', 'AD' or 'NIL')

previous_headings: Using the Package > Goodness of Fit Options
title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: argument alpha determines rejection threshold used comparing bootstrap test statistics. Smaller values imply conservative goodness--fit assessment.
code: GenErlang_Fit('Erlang', empiricaldata, alpha = VALUE) GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K, alpha = VALUE)

previous_headings: Using the Package > Goodness of Fit Options
what: Overriding choice of Number of Bootstraps
title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: Increasing number bootstrap samples improves stability precision p-value estimates‚Äîincreases runtime.
code: GenErlang_Fit('Erlang', empiricaldata, NumBootStraps = VALUE) GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K, NumBootStraps = VALUE)

title: Introduction to GenErlang Fit
text: ‚ÄúSmallest-K‚Äù routines automatically search simplest model remains statistically consistent observed data. process tests increasing values K identifies smallest structure passes selected goodness--fit criteria.detailed description section can found : FAQ: Smallest K Model. Erlang models, straightforward increasing-K search. Erlang‚ÄìExp models, users may optionally set SmallestKvalue limit search range computational speed.
code: GenErlang_Fit('Erlang', empiricaldata, SmallestK = TRUE)  GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K, SmallestK = TRUE) GenErlang_Fit('ErlangExp', empiricaldata, K, SmallestK = TRUE, SmallestKvalue = VALUE)

what: Fitting Erlang and Erlang‚ÄìExponential Time-to-Event Distributions
title: Fitting Erlang and Erlang‚ÄìExponential Time-to-Event Distributions
text: GenErlangFit R package fitting Erlang Erlang-Exponential models.

title: Fitting Erlang and Erlang‚ÄìExponential Time-to-Event Distributions
text: can install development version GenErlangFit GitHub :
code: install.packages("devtools") # If not already installed. devtools::install_github("vivekmurals/GenErlangFit", build_vignettes = TRUE)

title: Fitting Erlang and Erlang‚ÄìExponential Time-to-Event Distributions
text: package documentation available installation. quick introduction, see GettingStarted vignette running:
code: vignette("GettingStarted", package = "GenErlangFit")

title: Fitting Erlang and Erlang‚ÄìExponential Time-to-Event Distributions
text: simple example showing basic usage:
code: library(GenErlangFit) result <- GenErlang_Fit(data) print(result)

what: Compute CDF of Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpCDF_Func
title: Compute CDF of Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpCDF_Func
text: Calculates cumulative distribution function (CDF) values Erlang plus Exponential mixture distribution specified data points using numerical integration.

title: Compute CDF of Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpCDF_Func
code: ErlangExpCDF_Func(params, DatX, interval = 0.01)

title: Compute CDF of Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpCDF_Func
text: params Numeric vector length 3 containing parameters: Erlang shape parameter K (integer) Erlang rate parameter lambda Exponential rate parameter lambda DatX Numeric vector data points CDF evaluated. interval Numeric step size numerical integration grid (default 0.01).

title: Compute CDF of Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpCDF_Func
text: Numeric vector CDF values DatX.

title: Compute CDF of Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpCDF_Func
text: function computes PDF values grid using ErlangExp_Func numerically integrates using trapezoidal rule obtain CDF. results interpolated requested points.

title: Compute CDF of Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpCDF_Func
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ params <- c(3, 2, 1) x <- seq(0, 10, by = 0.1) cdf_vals <- ErlangExpCDF_Func(params, x) plot(x, cdf_vals, type = "l") } # }

what: Generate Random Samples from Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpRnd
title: Generate Random Samples from Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpRnd
text: Simulates random variates distribution defined sum Erlang-distributed random variable independent Exponential random variable.

title: Generate Random Samples from Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpRnd
code: ErlangExpRnd(params, rows, cols = 1)

title: Generate Random Samples from Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpRnd
text: params Numeric vector length 3 containing parameters: Erlang shape parameter K (integer) Erlang rate parameter lambda Exponential rate parameter lambda rows Integer, number rows output sample matrix. cols Integer, number columns output sample matrix (default 1).

title: Generate Random Samples from Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpRnd
text: Numeric matrix random samples dimensions rows √ó cols.

title: Generate Random Samples from Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpRnd
text: Random samples generated independently sampling Erlang Exponential components summing . output reshaped matrix.

title: Generate Random Samples from Erlang + Exponential Mixture Distribution ‚Äî ErlangExpRnd
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ params <- c(3, 2, 1) samples <- ErlangExpRnd(params, rows = 100, cols = 1) hist(samples, breaks = 30) } # }

what: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model (Version 2) ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2
title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model (Version 2) ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2
text: Fits empirical data mixture Erlang Exponential distributions using Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE), options goodness--fit testing via bootstrapping adaptive search shape parameter K.

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model (Version 2) ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2
code: ErlangExp_Fit_v2(empiricaldata, K, ...)

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model (Version 2) ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2
text: empiricaldata Numeric vector observed data. K Integer initial guess Erlang shape parameter. ... Optional named arguments override defaults: Alpha Significance level goodness--fit test. Default = 0.05. pvaloption Goodness--fit metric: "KS", "CvM", "AD", "NIL". Default = "KS". InitialguessErLam Initial guess Erlang rate parameter. Default = 3. SmallestK Logical. TRUE, searches smallest acceptable K alpha. Default = FALSE. SmallestKValue Initial smallest K value search. Default = -1 (auto). ShowFigures Logical. TRUE, generates diagnostic plots. Default = TRUE. FixedK Logical. TRUE, fits specified K without adaptive search. Default = FALSE. KWindowSize Window size around K adaptive search. Default = 1. NumBootstraps Number bootstrap samples p-value estimation. Default = round(10 * 10 / Alpha).

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model (Version 2) ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2
text: list containing: Best list best fit parameters, p-value, goodness--fit metrics. Smallest SmallestK = TRUE, results smallest acceptable K. AllFits fit results across searched K window (unless FixedK = TRUE).

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model (Version 2) ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2
text: function fits Erlang + Exponential mixture model input data, optionally performs bootstrap-based goodness--fit tests, can generate diagnostic plots fit. supports adaptive search shape parameter K fitting fixed K.

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model (Version 2) ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(200, rate = 0.5) fit <- ErlangExp_Fit_v2(data, K = 2, Alpha = 0.05, ShowFigures = TRUE) print(fit$Best) } # }

what: Fit Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model with Fixed Shape Parameter K ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK
title: Fit Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model with Fixed Shape Parameter K ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK
text: Fits empirical data Erlang + Exponential mixture model using Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE), fixed Erlang shape parameter K. Optionally computes bootstrap-based goodness--fit p-values.

title: Fit Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model with Fixed Shape Parameter K ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK
code: ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK(empiricaldata, FixedKValue, ...)

title: Fit Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model with Fixed Shape Parameter K ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK
text: empiricaldata Numeric vector observed data. FixedKValue Integer specifying fixed Erlang shape parameter K. ... Optional named arguments override defaults: Alpha Significance level goodness--fit test. Default = 0.05. pvaloption Goodness--fit metric: "KS", "CvM", "AD", "NIL" (skip p-value). Default = "KS". InitialguessErlam Initial guess Erlang rate parameter. Default = 3. SmallestK Logical. used function included consistency. Default = FALSE. ShowFigures Logical. TRUE, generates diagnostic plots. Default = TRUE. NumBootstraps Number bootstrap samples p-value estimation. Default = round(10 * 10 / Alpha).

title: Fit Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model with Fixed Shape Parameter K ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK
text: list containing: K_star Estimated Erlang shape parameter (fixed input). ErlangLambda_star Estimated Erlang rate parameter. ExpLambda_star Estimated Exponential rate parameter. P_star Bootstrap p-value goodness--fit (computed). Q_Value Bootstrap q-value (computed). LogLikelihood Log-likelihood fitted model. metric_star Goodness--fit test statistic (computed). samplestats_star Bootstrap sample statistics (computed).

title: Fit Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model with Fixed Shape Parameter K ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK
text: function performs MLE estimate Erlang Exponential rate parameters, fixing Erlang shape parameter K. Goodness--fit testing via bootstrap optional controlled pvaloption argument.

title: Fit Erlang + Exponential Mixture Model with Fixed Shape Parameter K ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(200, rate = 0.5) fit_fixed <- ErlangExp_Fit_v2_FixedK(data, FixedKValue = 2, Alpha = 0.05) print(fit_fixed$ErlangLambda_star) } # }

what: Bootstrap-based Goodness-of-Fit Test for Erlang + Exponential Fit ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue
title: Bootstrap-based Goodness-of-Fit Test for Erlang + Exponential Fit ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue
text: Performs bootstrap hypothesis test assess goodness--fit empirical data Erlang + Exponential mixture model, using specified test statistic (Kolmogorov-Smirnov, Cram√©r-von Mises, Anderson-Darling).

title: Bootstrap-based Goodness-of-Fit Test for Erlang + Exponential Fit ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue
code: ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue(   empiricaldata,   k_star,   erlambda_star,   explambda_star,   s = length(empiricaldata),   n = 1000,   alpha = 0.05,   pvaloption = "KS",   ShowFigures = TRUE )

title: Bootstrap-based Goodness-of-Fit Test for Erlang + Exponential Fit ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue
text: empiricaldata Numeric vector observed data. k_star Integer Erlang shape parameter (fixed). erlambda_star Numeric Erlang rate parameter. explambda_star Numeric Exponential rate parameter. s Integer sample size bootstrap samples. Default length empiricaldata. n Integer number bootstrap samples generate. Default 1000. alpha Significance level hypothesis testing. Default 0.05. pvaloption Character specifying goodness--fit metric use: "KS" (Kolmogorov-Smirnov), "CvM" (Cram√©r-von Mises), "AD" (Anderson-Darling). Default "KS". ShowFigures Logical indicating whether generate diagnostic plots. Default TRUE (currently commented code).

title: Bootstrap-based Goodness-of-Fit Test for Erlang + Exponential Fit ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue
text: list containing: p_value Bootstrap p-value goodness--fit test. q_value Binary decision indicator: 1 = fail reject null, 0 = reject null. metric_star Observed test statistic value empirical data. sample_stats Vector test statistics bootstrap samples.

title: Bootstrap-based Goodness-of-Fit Test for Erlang + Exponential Fit ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue
text: function computes empirical CDF theoretical Erlang+Exponential CDF, calculates specified goodness--fit test statistic, uses bootstrap resampling estimate p-value test. also provides simple hypothesis test decision based significance level alpha.

title: Bootstrap-based Goodness-of-Fit Test for Erlang + Exponential Fit ‚Äî ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(200, rate = 0.5) fit <- ErlangExp_Fit_v2(data) pval_res <- ErlangExp_Fit_v2_Pvalue(data, fit$Best$K_star, fit$Best$ErlangLambda_star, fit$Best$ExpLambda_star) print(pval_res$p_value) } # }

what: Erlang + Exponential Mixture PDF and Log-Likelihood ‚Äî ErlangExp_Func
title: Erlang + Exponential Mixture PDF and Log-Likelihood ‚Äî ErlangExp_Func
text: Computes probability density function (PDF) values Erlang plus Exponential mixture distribution given data, calculates total log-likelihood.

title: Erlang + Exponential Mixture PDF and Log-Likelihood ‚Äî ErlangExp_Func
code: ErlangExp_Func(data, ErK, Erlam, Explam)

title: Erlang + Exponential Mixture PDF and Log-Likelihood ‚Äî ErlangExp_Func
text: data Numeric vector observed data points. ErK Integer shape parameter Erlang distribution. Erlam Numeric rate parameter Erlang distribution. Explam Numeric rate parameter Exponential distribution.

title: Erlang + Exponential Mixture PDF and Log-Likelihood ‚Äî ErlangExp_Func
text: list components: Probability Numeric vector PDF values data point. Likelihood Sum log PDF values (total log-likelihood).

title: Erlang + Exponential Mixture PDF and Log-Likelihood ‚Äî ErlangExp_Func
text: data point, numerically integrates Erlang + Exponential PDF using given parameters. Returns list containing vector PDF values data point sum log-likelihoods.

title: Erlang + Exponential Mixture PDF and Log-Likelihood ‚Äî ErlangExp_Func
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(100, rate = 0.5) res <- ErlangExp_Func(data, ErK = 3, Erlam = 2, Explam = 1) res$Likelihood } # }

what: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang + Exponential Mixture ‚Äî ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood
title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang + Exponential Mixture ‚Äî ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood
text: Computes negative log-likelihood Erlang + Exponential mixture distribution given Erlang rate parameter, data, Erlang shape parameter.

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang + Exponential Mixture ‚Äî ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood
code: ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood(ErlangLambda, data, K)

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang + Exponential Mixture ‚Äî ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood
text: ErlangLambda Numeric rate parameter Erlang component. data Numeric vector observed data. K Integer shape parameter Erlang distribution.

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang + Exponential Mixture ‚Äî ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood
text: Numeric value negative log-likelihood.

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang + Exponential Mixture ‚Äî ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood
text: Calculates exponential rate parameter mean constraint evaluates negative log-likelihood using Erlang + Exponential PDF implemented ErlangExp_Func. Returns Inf exponential parameter invalid (e.g., negative infinite) penalize invalid parameter sets.

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang + Exponential Mixture ‚Äî ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(100, rate = 0.5) negLL <- ErlangExp_NegLogLikelihood(3, data, 2) } # }

what: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang Distribution (Version 2) ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2
title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang Distribution (Version 2) ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2
text: Fits empirical data Erlang (Gamma integer shape) distribution using Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE), evaluates goodness--fit using bootstrap-based hypothesis testing.

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang Distribution (Version 2) ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2
code: Erlang_Fit_v2(empiricaldata, ...)

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang Distribution (Version 2) ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2
text: empiricaldata Numeric vector observed data. ... Optional named arguments override defaults: Alpha Significance level goodness--fit test. Default = 0.05. pvaloption Goodness--fit metric: "KS", "CvM", "AD". Default = "KS". InitialguessK Initial guess Erlang shape parameter. Default = 3. SmallestK Logical. TRUE, searches smallest acceptable K alpha. Default = FALSE. ShowFigures Logical. TRUE, generates plots. Default = TRUE. NumBootstraps Number bootstrap samples p-value estimation. Default = round(10 * 10 / Alpha).

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang Distribution (Version 2) ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2
text: list containing: Best list MLE estimates, p-value, log-likelihood, test metrics. Smallest SmallestK = TRUE, results smallest acceptable K.

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang Distribution (Version 2) ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2
text: function estimates Erlang parameters (shape K scale lambda) maximizing log-likelihood function, tests whether data consistent fitted model via bootstrap-based Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov () tests. Optionally, can also search smallest integer K still passes chosen significance threshold (SmallestK = TRUE).

title: Fit Empirical Data Using Erlang Distribution (Version 2) ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(200, rate = 0.5) fit <- Erlang_Fit_v2(data, Alpha = 0.05, pvaloption = "KS", ShowFigures = FALSE) fit$Best$K_star } # }

what: Bootstrap-Based Goodness-of-Fit for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue
title: Bootstrap-Based Goodness-of-Fit for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue
text: Computes bootstrap-based p-value Erlang model fit using Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov, Cram√©r‚Äìvon Mises, Anderson‚ÄìDarling statistics.

title: Bootstrap-Based Goodness-of-Fit for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue
code: Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue(   empiricaldata,   k_star,   lambda_star,   s = length(empiricaldata),   n = 1000,   alpha = 0.05,   pvaloption = "KS",   ShowFigures = TRUE )

title: Bootstrap-Based Goodness-of-Fit for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue
text: empiricaldata Numeric vector observed data. k_star Numeric, fitted Erlang shape parameter. lambda_star Numeric, fitted Erlang scale parameter. s Integer, number observations. Defaults length(empiricaldata). n Integer, number bootstrap samples. Default = 1000. alpha Numeric, significance level. Default = 0.05. pvaloption Character. Choice test statistic: "KS", "CvM", "AD". ShowFigures Logical. TRUE, produces optional plots (currently suppressed).

title: Bootstrap-Based Goodness-of-Fit for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue
text: list containing: p_value Bootstrap-estimated p-value. q_value Binary indicator (1 = fail reject, 0 = reject). metric_star Observed test statistic. sample_stats Bootstrap sample statistics.

title: Bootstrap-Based Goodness-of-Fit for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue
text: function compares empirical CDF observed data theoretical Erlang CDF computes test statistic. Bootstrap samples fitted Erlang model used estimate null distribution compute corresponding p-value.

title: Bootstrap-Based Goodness-of-Fit for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(200, rate = 0.5) fit <- Erlang_Fit_v2(data, ShowFigures = FALSE) pvals <- Erlang_Fit_v2_Pvalue(data, fit$Best$K_star, fit$Best$Lambda_star) } # }

what: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_NegLogLikelihood
title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_NegLogLikelihood
text: Computes negative log-likelihood (minimized) given Erlang (Gamma) shape parameter k data vector. scale parameter internally estimated \(lambda = mean(data) / k\).

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_NegLogLikelihood
code: Erlang_NegLogLikelihood(k, data)

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_NegLogLikelihood
text: k Numeric, Erlang shape parameter. data Numeric vector observed data.

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_NegLogLikelihood
text: Numeric scalar representing negative log-likelihood.

title: Negative Log-Likelihood for Erlang Distribution ‚Äî Erlang_NegLogLikelihood
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(200, rate = 0.5) Erlang_NegLogLikelihood(3, data) } # }

what: Generalized Erlang and Erlang-Exponential Distribution Fitting ‚Äî GenErlang_Fit
title: Generalized Erlang and Erlang-Exponential Distribution Fitting ‚Äî GenErlang_Fit
text: Fits empirical data Erlang Erlang-Exponential mixture models using maximum likelihood estimation. wrapper function calls appropriate specialized fitting routines based mode parameter.

title: Generalized Erlang and Erlang-Exponential Distribution Fitting ‚Äî GenErlang_Fit
code: GenErlang_Fit(mode, empiricaldata = NULL, K = NULL, ...)

title: Generalized Erlang and Erlang-Exponential Distribution Fitting ‚Äî GenErlang_Fit
text: mode Character string specifying model fit. Options "Erlang" "ErlangExp". Alternatively, mode numeric additional arguments, interpreted empirical data, models fit. empiricaldata Numeric vector empirical data fitted. Required mode "Erlang" "ErlangExp". K Integer specifying initial guess shape parameter K (number Erlang phases) "ErlangExp" mode. Required mode = "ErlangExp". ... Additional optional parameters passed underlying fitting functions. example: SmallestK Logical. Whether search smallest acceptable K satisfying goodness--fit. model-specific options.

title: Generalized Erlang and Erlang-Exponential Distribution Fitting ‚Äî GenErlang_Fit
text: list containing fitting results: "Erlang" mode, returns result list Erlang_Fit_v2. "ErlangExp" mode, returns result list ErlangExp_Fit_v2. empirical data provided (numeric mode), returns list Erlang Erlang-Exp fit results.

title: Generalized Erlang and Erlang-Exponential Distribution Fitting ‚Äî GenErlang_Fit
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- rexp(100, rate = 0.1) GenErlang_Fit("Erlang", data, SmallestK = TRUE) GenErlang_Fit("ErlangExp", data, K = 3) GenErlang_Fit(data) # fits both models and returns results } # }

title: GenErlangFit (development version)
text: Initial development version.
